title: Audit and backfill beads for Dec 2-14 work
description: Audited beads for completeness over past two weeks. Backfilled missing entries: (1) Dec 8-9 warehouse papers work (organization, friendly review verification, Zuckerman evaluation, Dan Sholler coauthorship, Overleaf packages, cover letters, paper-mining-agents restructure). (2) Dec 2-7 TM464 grading experiment (design, implementation, calibration with Bradley-Terry analysis showing 580x quality differences at ceiling, AI repo grading, Sprint 2 final grades). Updated beads tool from v0.24.2 to v0.29.0.

title: Add Dan Sholler as coauthor to all 4 warehouse papers
description: Added Dan Sholler as second author on all 4 warehouse automation papers. Converted voice from first person singular ('I') to first person plural ('we') throughout. Papers 1 and 4 already used 'we'; papers 2 and 3 required systematic conversion via regex.

title: ASQ R2 Revision: Developmental Uncertainty
description: Finalized ASQ R2 resubmission. Key changes: (1) Addressed competing explanation that Mexico location (not uncertainty reduction) stopped skill development—reframed to show CA workers DID build skills, but in manufacturing where uncertainty remained. (2) Added Phase 1 mechanical engineering alongside digital. (3) Named phenomenon 'developmental uncertainty' with subtitle 'When Coordination Demands Enable Occupational Mobility Across Status Boundaries'. (4) Created ASQ qualitative naming typology guide. (5) Created Dan Sholler coauthorship invitation with abstracts for all 4 warehouse automation papers. Final package at projects/engineering-skill/ASQ-resubmit/submission-package/ASQ-submission.zip

title: ManSci Inverse Paper: Quantitative Analysis of Human-AI Task Evolution
description: A quant-major version of the engineering-skill paper for Management Science. Uses 33M+ teleop/production records as primary evidence to show phase transitions in human-robot task allocation, operator learning curves, and uncertainty consumption as automation matures. Qualitative data serves to interpret quantitative patterns rather than drive narrative. Distinct contribution from the ASQ/OrgSci qual-major submission.

title: Verify friendly reviewer critiques for papers 2, 3, and 4
description: Systematically verified empirical claims in friendly reviews. Paper 2: Found real bug in placebo test (shuffle-merge logic producing incorrect control groups). Papers 3 and 4: No empirical bugs found—critiques focused on framing/theory rather than data issues. Created CRITIQUE_VERIFICATION.md files documenting each verification.

title: Grade student AI repository entries
description: Extended grading system to handle student GitHub repositories (shared-ai-repository-entry-*). Cloned 49 student repos, extracted README/documentation content, graded against AI Repository rubric. Generated grades and detailed feedback for each submission.

title: Rubric calibration analysis with Bradley-Terry rankings
description: Ran consistency verification on graded submissions. Key finding: severe ceiling effects—90%+ of submissions scored 'Excellent' on most criteria. Bradley-Terry pairwise comparisons revealed 580x quality differences between submissions with identical rubric scores. Rubrics treat 'meets basic requirements' as 'Excellent'. Recommended adding 'Outstanding' tier and raising thresholds. Report includes specific calibration recommendations for each rubric.

title: Design Monte Carlo grading system for TM464
description: Designed and architected Monte Carlo LLM-based grading system for TM464 'Learning to Work with Intelligent Machines' course. System uses multiple (5) grading runs per criterion to reduce variance, with SQLite storage, statistical aggregation, flagging for high-variance items, and optional judge layer. Architecture: PDF loader → Grading engine → Aggregator → Judge → Reports. Estimated cost ~$10-20 for full course grading.

title: Implement and run Monte Carlo grading pipeline
description: Built full grading pipeline: PDF text extraction, rubric definitions (3x3x3, Lean PRD, Skill Impact, Prompt Crafting), async grading with Haiku, statistical aggregation. Graded ~150 submissions across 5 assignment types. System stored all runs in SQLite (31MB grading.db), generated per-student reports and Canvas-ready CSVs.

title: Grade Sprint 2 assignments and finalize course grades
description: Graded Sprint 2 assignments: Lightning Talks (individual and team), Lean PRD Sprint 2, Skill Impact Sprint 2, Shared AI Repo Written component. Merged all grades into Canvas export format. Final output: complete grade sheet ready for Canvas upload.

title: Create cover letters and journal targeting for all 4 papers
description: Drafted submission cover letters matching Matt's prior letter style. Assignments: Paper 1 (Wait and See) → ASQ (Beth Bechky). Paper 2 (Learning to Automate) → Management Science. Paper 3 (When Misfit Motivates) → ASQ (Erin Reid). Paper 4 (Developmental Uncertainty) → ASQ (Beth Bechky). Each letter includes internal notes on potential associate editors and external reviewers.

title: Expand Paper 1 (automation-turnover) to full Management Science length
description: Expanded literature review, data section, methodology, and discussion to ~10,000 words. Added detailed subsections on task-based framework, anticipation effects, identification concerns. Paper is now ready for Overleaf submission.

title: Expand Paper 2 (flexible staffing-productivity) to full length with figures
description: Expanded to ~8,000 words with detailed lit review on turnover contagion and learning curves. Generated 4 figures: monthly patterns, learning curve, turnover contagion, peak comparison. Paper captures seasonal paradox, contagion effect (0.66 coefficient), and 101-day productivity plateau.

title: Create paper-mining agents suite
description: Built 6-agent system for data-to-paper workflow: data-explorer, pattern-hunter, twist-finder, paper-architect, hypothesis-tester, paper-drafter. Each agent has focused prompt. Based on Adam Davidson's multi-agent approach. Located at ~/knowledge-work/projects/paper-mining-agents/

title: Organize research projects into knowledge-work directory
description: Moved warehouse-automation-papers and gap-incentive-pay from Desktop to ~/knowledge-work/projects/. Created clean project structure for ongoing research.

title: Explore Gap incentive pay data for Paper 3
description: Initial exploration of GROW incentive pay data: 68,860 worker-month obs, status types (FT/Seasonal/PT), performance metrics, payout data. Potential papers on incentive effects, retention, status transitions. Data in ~/knowledge-work/projects/gap-incentive-pay/

title: Clean and validate Gap GROW incentive data
description: Validate 68,860 worker-month observations. Check for missing values, outliers in performance metrics and payouts. Ensure status transitions (FT/Seasonal/PT) are consistent. Create analysis-ready dataset.

title: Identify key patterns in GROW payout structure
description: Analyze payout distributions by status type, tenure, performance tier. Look for discontinuities, threshold effects, seasonal variation. Document incentive design features that could drive behavior.

title: Literature review on incentive pay effects
description: Review literature on performance-based pay, especially in hourly/warehouse contexts. Key topics: incentive design, gaming behavior, retention effects, productivity responses, peer effects in incentive settings.

title: Develop hypotheses for Paper 3
description: Synthesize patterns from data exploration (kw-21) with literature (kw-22) to formulate testable hypotheses. Identify the 'twist' or counterintuitive finding that makes this paper distinctive.

title: Run initial models for Paper 3
description: Estimate primary specifications testing hypotheses from kw-23. Include robustness checks, placebo tests, identification validation. Generate key figures and tables.

title: Draft Paper 3 (Gap incentive pay)
description: Write full manuscript integrating lit review, data description, methodology, results, and discussion. Target ~8,000-10,000 words for top management journal.

title: TM464: Apply Audit Opt-Out Grade Spreading After Review
description:
14 students opted to drop Skill-Environment Audit 1 and have Audit 2 count for 15%.

**Pending:** Review Audit 2 grades via grade-review.html interface first, then re-run apply_audit_opt_out.py to spread calibrated scores.

**Students:** Andy Quach, Justin Hill-Kocak, Christina Hefan Cui, Kilee Knutson, Sam Rappoport, Mikey Luk, Aishwarya Nandkishorji Mundada, Patrick Norton, Victoria Kao, Nicolla Eddy Wopara, Adailton Nali, Ziang Zhu, Yun-Pei Wei, Maximilian Lemos

**Files:** projects/grading-experiment-2025/apply_audit_opt_out.py, projects/grading-experiment-2025/PENDING_TASKS.md

**After review:** python3 apply_audit_opt_out.py → upload CSV to Canvas

title: TM464: Manual Grade - chensiding & sunyang Action Memo
description:
Two students have ERROR ratings for Action Memo Strategic Quality criterion (all LLM runs failed JSON parsing):
- chensiding: 0/20 on Action Memo
- sunyang: 0/20 on Action Memo

These need manual grading. Filter by 'Grading Error' in grade-review.html to find them.

**Context:** skill_audit_2 grading session 26, rubric in rubrics/skill_audit_2.json

title: Add living_paper module with pre-review workflow
description: Integrated living_paper module into paper-mining-agents. Core features: claim-evidence traceability, verification workflow, pre-review contested claim reports. Schema supports claims, evidence, links with verification status. Pre-review workflow surfaces challenges before submission, applies quant/qual hierarchy for mechanism adjudication. Synced quant/qual hierarchy nuance across repos.

title: Add living paper v0.5: reviewer interface and PII redaction
description: Major living paper upgrade to v0.5. New features: (1) reviewer_app.py - Flask web interface for verification. (2) redact.py + entities.yaml - PII entity redaction system. (3) export-html - static HTML reviewer (no server needed). (4) export-package - complete reviewer folder with double-click launchers for Mac/Windows. (5) Prevalence metadata fields for ethnographic claims (informant_coverage, contradicting_count, saturation_note, prevalence_basis). Generated reviewer packages for all 4 warehouse papers. Value: External verification accessible to non-technical reviewers.

title: Add comparison with Nguyen & Welch (2025) critique of GenAI in qual research
description: Added comparison between paper-mining-agents approach and Nguyen & Welch (2025) critique of GenAI in qualitative research. Key distinctions: (1) Analyst-in-the-loop vs automation, (2) Structured claims with evidence vs black-box themes, (3) Transparent provenance vs hidden reasoning, (4) Verification workflow vs output trust.

title: Create Overleaf-ready submission packages for all 4 papers
description: Generated journal-ready zip packages for Overleaf upload: wait-and-see-overleaf.zip (272KB), learning-to-automate-overleaf.zip (522KB), when-misfit-motivates-overleaf.zip (96KB), developmental-uncertainty-overleaf.zip (61KB). Each contains main.tex, references.bib, figures, and online_appendix.tex where applicable.

title: Integrate Zuckerman checks earlier in paper-mining-agents workflow
description: Restructured paper-mining-agents to catch framing problems earlier. Added two-stage Zuckerman integration: (1) /eval-zuckerman-lite after /hunt-patterns—early puzzle check before investing in theory. (2) /eval-zuckerman after /smith-frames—full 10-criteria check before verification. Pipeline expanded from 8 to 10 steps. Key insight: Zuckerman is puzzle-first; prior workflow was data-first. Now hybrid.

title: Add style_enforcer module for qualitative management paper standards
description: Built style_enforcer.py module for paper-mining-agents. Validates papers against qualitative management journal standards: passive voice limits, hedging, nominalization, paragraph structure, evidence-claim ratios. Includes validator.py for rules and examples/ with good/bad patterns. Fixed validator to allow ordinal transitions (first/second/third) and skip tablenotes.

title: Organize warehouse automation papers into clean directory structure
description: Restructured all 4 warehouse automation papers into consistent directories: wait-and-see-paper/, learning-to-automate-paper/, when-misfit-motivates-paper/, developmental-uncertainty-paper/. Each has submission/, reviews/, data/, analysis/, and prior-drafts/ subdirectories. Moved legacy content to _archive/.

title: Zuckerman criteria evaluation for all 4 warehouse papers
description: Evaluated all 4 papers against Zuckerman's 10 Tips for Article-Writers. Results: Paper 1 (Wait and See): Already strong. Paper 2 (Learning to Automate): 8/10—needed to build up null, consolidate propositions from 5 to 3. Paper 3 (When Misfit Motivates): 9/10—best overall, tightened theory section. Paper 4 (Developmental Uncertainty): 8.5/10—clarified audience (cross-status contact skeptics), positioned contingency theory as interpretive lens. Created ZUCKERMAN_EVAL.md files for teaching purposes.
